column4: Hi.  I just read about Ubuntu.  It sounds like a pretty cool project.  I've been using Debian testing for a while and I'm pretty happy with it, but I've felt that packages don't always work together as smoothly on the desktop as you would like.
So I've often wished someone would put together and configure a set of them that just work, and it looks like that's what Ubuntu kind of does.
give us a for example
thats the general idea ;)

Well, for example, getting a web browser mailto link to open a tab in an already running browser rather than a) spawning a new instance of the same browser or b) a completely different "default browser".
Or all these different programs dealing with sound in a different way, OSS, ALSA, etc.
Usually you can make it work, but getting all your software on the same page is a real chore.
I think opening a new browser is deliberate - in windows when using IE it sometimes looses the page you had and replaces it
I find the integration works very well - a lot of the time stuff just works - expecialy sound - video - CD burning.
You're talking about which distro now?
most linux distros - I was just kind of guessing why it opens a new browser - I suppose a new tab would be better
yes.
Well, it took me a while to get everything working correctly when I switched from OSS to ALSA.
My point is really that because debian aims for a lot of flexability, things can't be set by default to interact in the best way.
Because "the best way" depends a lot on what you have installed.
all I can say is that since I have installed Ubuntu I have has the best set up Linux distro ever and it hass been very painless;)
I like the idea of having a distro where the default stuff works painlessly, and you have the option to stray off the beaten path (and take the consequences) if you like.
I guess one of the things about Ubuntu is they try to choose one of eatch type of app and install it by default
It all depends on if you agree with there choices
so do I ;)
thats a very good question, i'me not sure.  One for the mailing list I guess
Ah.  Well, it's a moot point for now, as my desktop system is a notebook, and I read that notebook support isn't really there yet in Ubuntu.
Which is understandable, since that seems to be quite difficult and the distro is pretty new.
I was interested, though, and will keep my eye on it.
